{"uri": "8155384371", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "15:30:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T15:30:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T15:29:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.dawn.com/news/1836898", "title": "Blinken says Washington approved use of US weapons by Ukraine inside Russia", "body": "US President Joe Biden approved Ukraine using US weapons to strike targets inside Russia that were attacking the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, after Kyiv sought authorisation from Washington in recent weeks, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken confirmed on Friday.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference in Prague after an informal meeting of Nato foreign ministers, Blinken did not specifically say whether Biden's authorisation could expand to include other Russian cities and targets deeper inside Russia.\n\nOutgunned and outmanned on the battlefield, Kyiv has been increasing pressure on its Western allies to be able to launch offensive strikes at military targets inside Russia to better repel Russian advances.\n\nBlinken said Washington's move, a marked change in policy by Biden, who steadfastly refused to allow Ukraine to use American weaponry inside Russia, was a result of the US adjusting and adapting to the battleground. Now, he said, the US is responding to what it has seen in and around the Kharkiv region.\n\n\"Over the past few weeks, Ukraine came to us and asked for the authorisation to use weapons that we're providing to defend against this aggression, including against Russian forces that are massing on the Russian side of the border and then attacking into Ukraine,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"And that went right to the president, and as you've heard, he's approved [the] use of our weapons for that purpose. Going forward, we'll continue to do what we've been doing, which is as necessary adapt and adjust,\" Blinken said.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is 30 kilometres from the border with Russia.\n\nIt is the second time this year that Biden has quietly relaxed his policy on weapons supplies for Ukraine. Earlier this year, he bent to calls to send long-range missiles known as ATACMS to Kyiv.\n\nUS officials said on Thursday that US policy would continue to prohibit the Ukrainian military from using ATACMS, which have a range of up to 300km, and other long-range US weapons for deep strikes inside Russia.\n\nThe US is the biggest supplier of weapons to Ukraine in its battle against the full-scale invasion launched by Russian President Vladimir Putin in February 2022.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Friday that Ukraine using any Western weapon to strike Russian territory is \"a question of time\".\n\n\"I think that using any weapon, Western kind of weapon, on the territory of Russia is a question of time. Otherwise, it is not about just peace,\" Zelensky told reporters on a visit to Stockholm.\n\nUkraine has stressed the urgency for the use of Western-supplied arms to conduct strikes inside Russia as it defends against Russian advances in the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nThis spring, Ukraine found itself on the back foot in the 27-month-old full-scale invasion as it faces delays in military aid from the US, increased attacks on its energy infrastructure and Russia's push to expand the frontline.\n\nZelenskiy said Ukraine \"got [a] message from the American side early in the morning\" which signified a \"step forward\" in defending people in villages near the border with Russia. He did not disclose additional details on the communication with the US.\n\nZelenskiy said he did not yet know the possible restrictions related to the use of long-awaited F-16 fighter jets, but appealed to the question of fairness in deliberations, saying Ukraine should be able to retaliate against Russian strikes.\n\nGermany, another major ally, signalled its openness to Ukraine's use of its weapons to strike military sites fuelling attacks on the Kharkiv region.\n\nFrance has taken a similar stance, saying Ukraine should be allowed to strike military sites Russia is using to attack its territory.", "source": {"uri": "dawn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Dawn"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@dawn.com", "name": "Reuters", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": {"uri": "8155422747", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "15:58:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T15:58:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T15:58:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/germany-says-ukraine-can-use-its-weapons-against-targets-in-russia-after-the-u-s-also-eases-its-stance", "title": "Germany says Ukraine can use its weapons against targets in Russia after the U.S. also eases its stance", "body": "KYIV, Ukraine (AP) -- Germany joined the United States on Friday in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying -- a significant policy change that comes as depleted Ukrainian troops are losing ground in the war.\n\nUkrainian officials have expressed frustration over restrictions on the use of Western weapons -- especially as the border region of Kharkiv has endured a Russian onslaught this month that has stretched Kyiv's outgunned and outmanned forces.\n\nWATCH NOW: Biden authorizes Ukraine to fire U.S. weapons into parts of Russia\n\nBoth Germany and the U.S. specifically authorized the use of weapons to defend Kharkiv, whose capital city of the same name lies only 20 kilometers (12 miles) from Russia. Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment building in the city overnight, Ukrainian officials said, killing at least six people.\n\nBeyond offering Ukraine a chance of better protecting Kharkiv by targeting Russian capabilities in the region, it's not clear what effect the easing of restrictions might have on the direction of the conflict in what is proving to be a critical period. But it drew a furious response from Moscow and warnings it could draw Russia into war with NATO.\n\nThe German government said Ukraine can use weapons it supplies against positions just over the border, from where Russia launches its attacks on Kharkiv. A day earlier, U.S. President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the region, according to U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken.\n\nBlinken said Kyiv had asked Washington for permission to use U.S.-supplied weapons against the Kremlin's troops amassing on the Russian side of the border for attacks inside Ukraine. Biden's approval was for that purpose, Blinken said at a meeting of NATO foreign ministers in Prague.\n\nU.S. officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nIn response, Dmitry Medvedev, the deputy head of Russia's Security Council, said Friday that \"Ukraine and its NATO allies will receive such a devastating response that the alliance won't be able to avoid entering the conflict\" -- an eventuality that Western governments have ruled out.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to ease the restrictions on their weapons because of the risk it would provoke Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict. Last week, Russia said military drills involving tactical nuclear weapons had begun.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders have pushed for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners.\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in U.S. military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has also slowed crucial deliveries to Ukraine.\n\nThe German government statement noted that, in recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks on the Kharkiv region, in particular from areas just over the border in Russia.\n\n\"Together we are convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement said. \"For this, it can also use the weapons delivered for that purpose in accordance with its international legal commitments, including the ones delivered by us,\" it added.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nNATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said Friday he supported lifting the limits on Ukraine's use of Western weaponry, saying it's \"a matter of upholding international law -- Ukraine's right to self-defense.\"\n\n\"Putin wanted to deter the NATO allies from supporting Ukraine. But we are not and we will not be deterred,\" Stoltenberg said.\n\nSwedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billstr\u00f6m noted that his country had not restricted Ukraine's use of its weapons at all, while Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said Rome won't let Kyiv use Italian weapons outside its territory.\n\nIn Moscow, Medvedev repeated Russian warnings that the steps being taken could set NATO and Russia on the path to a nuclear conflict. \"It's not an attempt to scare or any sort of a nuclear bluff,\" he said.\n\nRussia's newly appointed defense minister, Andrei Belousov, claimed Friday that Russian troops are \"advancing in all tactical directions,\" including in the Kharkiv region where he said they have pushed Ukrainian forces back by as much as 9 kilometers (5 miles). Russian forces captured 28 towns and villages over the past month, he said.\n\nOverall since the start of the year, Russian forces have taken control of 880 square kilometers (340 square miles) of territory, he added.\n\nIt was not possible to verify his battlefield claims.\n\nOvernight into Friday, Russia launched five ballistic missiles at Kharkiv, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov.\n\nSix people were killed, according to Syniehubov, and at least 25 were wounded.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles -- the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. Russia used the method in Syria's civil war.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy region further north, according to Ukrainian officials.\n\n___\n\nLee and Janicek reported from Prague. Associated Press writers Geir Moulson in Berlin and Ellen Knickmeyer, Aamer Madhani and Zeke Miller in Washington contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "pbs.org", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8155540963", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "17:30:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T17:30:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T17:29:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.mercurynews.com/2024/05/31/berlin-agrees-to-let-ukraine-use-german-weapons-to-strike-russia/", "title": "Berlin agrees to let Ukraine use German weapons to strike Russia", "body": "Both Germany and the U.S. specifically authorized defense of Kharkiv\n\nBy Illia Novikov, Matthew Lee and Karel Janicek | Associated Press\n\nKYIV, Ukraine -- Germany joined the United States on Friday in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying -- a significant policy change that comes as depleted Ukrainian troops are losing ground in the war.\n\nUkrainian officials have expressed frustration over restrictions on the use of Western weapons -- especially as the border region of Kharkiv has endured a Russian onslaught this month that has stretched Kyiv's outgunned and outmanned forces.\n\nBoth Germany and the U.S. specifically authorized the use of weapons to defend Kharkiv, whose capital city of the same name lies only 20 kilometers (12 miles) from Russia. Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment building in the city overnight, Ukrainian officials said, killing at least six people.\n\nBeyond offering Ukraine a chance of better protecting Kharkiv by targeting Russian capabilities in the region, it's not clear what effect the easing of restrictions might have on the direction of the conflict in what is proving to be a critical period. But it drew a furious response from Moscow and warnings it could draw Russia into war with NATO.\n\nThe German government said Ukraine can use weapons it supplies against positions just over the border, from where Russia launches its attacks on Kharkiv. A day earlier, U.S. President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the region, according to U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken.\n\nBlinken said Kyiv had asked Washington for permission to use U.S.-supplied weapons against the Kremlin's troops amassing on the Russian side of the border for attacks inside Ukraine. Biden's approval was for that purpose, Blinken said at a meeting of NATO foreign ministers in Prague.\n\nU.S. officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nIn response, Dmitry Medvedev, the deputy head of Russia's Security Council, said Friday that \"Ukraine and its NATO allies will receive such a devastating response that the alliance won't be able to avoid entering the conflict\" -- an eventuality that Western governments have ruled out.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to ease the restrictions on their weapons because of the risk it would provoke Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict. Last week, Russia said military drills involving tactical nuclear weapons had begun.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders have pushed for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners.\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in U.S. military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has also slowed crucial deliveries to Ukraine.\n\nThe German government statement noted that, in recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks on the Kharkiv region, in particular from areas just over the border in Russia.\n\n\"Together we are convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement said. \"For this, it can also use the weapons delivered for that purpose in accordance with its international legal commitments, including the ones delivered by us,\" it added.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nNATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said Friday he supported lifting the limits on Ukraine's use of Western weaponry, saying it's \"a matter of upholding international law -- Ukraine's right to self-defense.\"\n\n\"Putin wanted to deter the NATO allies from supporting Ukraine. But we are not and we will not be deterred,\" Stoltenberg said.\n\nSwedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billstr\u00f6m noted that his country had not restricted Ukraine's use of its weapons at all, while Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said Rome won't let Kyiv use Italian weapons outside its territory.\n\nIn Moscow, Medvedev repeated Russian warnings that the steps being taken could set NATO and Russia on the path to a nuclear conflict. \"It's not an attempt to scare or any sort of a nuclear bluff,\" he said.\n\nRussia's newly appointed defense minister, Andrei Belousov, claimed Friday that Russian troops are \"advancing in all tactical directions,\" including in the Kharkiv region where he said they have pushed Ukrainian forces back by as much as 9 kilometers (5 miles). Russian forces captured 28 towns and villages over the past month, he said.\n\nOverall since the start of the year, Russian forces have taken control of 880 square kilometers (340 square miles) of territory, he added.\n\nIt was not possible to verify his battlefield claims.\n\nOvernight into Friday, Russia launched five ballistic missiles at Kharkiv, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov.\n\nSix people were killed, according to Syniehubov, and at least 25 were wounded.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles -- the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. Russia used the method in Syria's civil war.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy region further north, according to Ukrainian officials.", "source": {"uri": "mercurynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "San Jose Mercury News"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-374667443", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "15:26:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T15:26:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T15:11:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://abc7.com/post/president-joe-biden-ukraine-weapons-berlin-lets-ukraine/14895549/", "title": "Ukraine war: US eases stance on Ukraine using weapons on Russian targets; Germany follows suit", "body": "U.S. President Joe Biden on Thursday gave Ukraine a green light to strike with American weapons at Russia military assets targeting the region.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Germany joined the United States on Friday in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying - a significant policy change that comes as depleted Ukrainian troops are losing ground in the war.\n\nUkrainian officials have expressed frustration over restrictions on the use of Western weapons - especially as the border region of Kharkiv has endured a Russian onslaught this month that has stretched Kyiv's outgunned and outmanned forces.\n\nBoth Germany and the U.S. specifically authorized the use of weapons to defend Kharkiv, whose capital city of the same name lies only 20 kilometers (12 miles) from Russia. Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment building in the city overnight, Ukrainian officials said, killing at least five people.\n\nBeyond offering Ukraine a chance of better protecting Kharkiv by targeting Russian capabilities in the region, it's not clear what effect the easing of restrictions might have on the direction of the conflict in what is proving to be a critical period. But it drew a furious response from Moscow and warnings it could draw Russia into war with NATO.\n\nThe German government said Ukraine can use weapons it supplies against positions just over the border, from where Russia launches its attacks on Kharkiv. A day earlier, U.S. President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the region, according to U.S. officials familiar with the matter.\n\nIn response, Dmitry Medvedev, the deputy head of Russia's Security Council, said Friday that \"Ukraine and its NATO allies will receive such a devastating response that the alliance won't be able to avoid entering the conflict\" - an eventuality that Western governments have ruled out.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to ease the restrictions on their weapons because of the risk it would provoke Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict. Last week, Russia said military drills involving tactical nuclear weapons had begun.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders have pushed for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners.\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in U.S. military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has also slowed crucial deliveries to Ukraine.\n\nThe German government statement noted that, in recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks on the Kharkiv region, in particular from areas just over the border in Russia.\n\n\"Together we are convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement said. \"For this, it can also use the weapons delivered for that purpose in accordance with its international legal commitments, including the ones delivered by us,\" it added.\n\nBiden's decision allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official told The Associated Press.\n\nSEE ALSO: At least 16 killed in Russian strike on hardware store in Kharkiv\n\nBut the officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nNATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said Friday he supported lifting the limits on Ukraine's use of Western weaponry, saying it's \"a matter of upholding international law - Ukraine's right to self-defense.\"\n\nSwedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billstr\u00f6m noted that his country had not restricted Ukraine's use of its weapons at all, while Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said Rome won't let Kyiv use Italian weapons outside its territory.\n\nIn Moscow, Medvedev repeated Russian warnings that the steps being taken could set NATO and Russia on the path to a nuclear conflict. \"It's not an attempt to scare or any sort of a nuclear bluff,\" he said.\n\nRussia's newly appointed defense minister, Andrei Belousov, claimed Friday that Russian troops are \"advancing in all tactical directions,\" including in the Kharkiv region where he said they have pushed Ukrainian forces back by as much as 9 kilometers (5 miles). Russian forces captured 28 towns and villages over the past month, he said.\n\nOverall since the start of the year, Russian forces have taken control of 880 square kilometers (340 square miles) of territory, he added.\n\nIt was not possible to verify his battlefield claims.\n\nOvernight into Friday, Russia launched five ballistic missiles at Kharkiv, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov.\n\nFive people were killed, according to Kharkiv Mayor Ihor Terekhov, while the governor said at least 25 were wounded.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles - the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. Russia used the method in Syria's civil war.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy {"uri": "2024-05-374658510", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "15:17:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T15:17:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T15:13:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.kimt.com/news/berlin-lets-ukraine-use-german-weapons-against-targets-in-russia-after-the-us-also-eases/article_52eec54c-1f60-11ef-9011-03fd852a0c22.html", "title": "Berlin lets Ukraine use German weapons against targets in Russia after the US also eases its stance", "body": "KYIV, Ukraine (AP) -- Germany joined the United States on Friday in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying -- a significant policy change that comes as depleted Ukrainian troops are losing ground in the war.\n\nUkrainian officials have expressed frustration over restrictions on the use of Western weapons -- especially as the border region of Kharkiv has endured a Russian onslaught this month that has stretched Kyiv's outgunned and outmanned forces.\n\nBoth Germany and the U.S. specifically authorized the use of weapons to defend Kharkiv, whose capital city of the same name lies only 20 kilometers (12 miles) from Russia. Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment building in the city overnight, Ukrainian officials said, killing at least six people.\n\nBeyond offering Ukraine a chance of better protecting Kharkiv by targeting Russian capabilities in the region, it's not clear what effect the easing of restrictions might have on the direction of the conflict in what is proving to be a critical period. But it drew a furious response from Moscow and warnings it could draw Russia into war with NATO.\n\nThe German government said Ukraine can use weapons it supplies against positions just over the border, from where Russia launches its attacks on Kharkiv. A day earlier, U.S. President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the region, according to U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken.\n\nBlinken said Kyiv had asked Washington for permission to use U.S.-supplied weapons against the Kremlin's troops amassing on the Russian side of the border for attacks inside Ukraine. Biden's approval was for that purpose, Blinken said at a meeting of NATO foreign ministers in Prague.\n\nU.S. officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nIn response, Dmitry Medvedev, the deputy head of Russia's Security Council, said Friday that \"Ukraine and its NATO allies will receive such a devastating response that the alliance won't be able to avoid entering the conflict\" -- an eventuality that Western governments have ruled out.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to ease the restrictions on their weapons because of the risk it would provoke Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict. Last week, Russia said military drills involving tactical nuclear weapons had begun.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders have pushed for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners.\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in U.S. military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has also slowed crucial deliveries to Ukraine.\n\nThe German government statement noted that, in recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks on the Kharkiv region, in particular from areas just over the border in Russia.\n\n\"Together we are convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement said. \"For this, it can also use the weapons delivered for that purpose in accordance with its international legal commitments, including the ones delivered by us,\" it added.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nNATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said Friday he supported lifting the limits on Ukraine's use of Western weaponry, saying it's \"a matter of upholding international law -- Ukraine's right to self-defense.\"\n\n\"Putin wanted to deter the NATO allies from supporting Ukraine. But we are not and we will not be deterred,\" Stoltenberg said.\n\nSwedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billstr\u00f6m noted that his country had not restricted Ukraine's use of its weapons at all, while Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said Rome won't let Kyiv use Italian weapons outside its territory.\n\nIn Moscow, Medvedev repeated Russian warnings that the steps being taken could set NATO and Russia on the path to a nuclear conflict. \"It's not an attempt to scare or any sort of a nuclear bluff,\" he said.\n\nRussia's newly appointed defense minister, Andrei Belousov, claimed Friday that Russian troops are \"advancing in all tactical directions,\" including in the Kharkiv region where he said they have pushed Ukrainian forces back by as much as 9 kilometers (5 miles). Russian forces captured 28 towns and villages over the past month, he said.\n\nOverall since the start of the year, Russian forces have taken control of 880 square kilometers (340 square miles) of territory, he added.\n\nIt was not possible to verify his battlefield claims.\n\nOvernight into Friday, Russia launched five ballistic missiles at Kharkiv, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov.\n\nSix people were killed, according to Syniehubov, and at least 25 were wounded.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles -- the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. Russia used the method in Syria's civil war.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy {"uri": "2024-05-374737294", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "16:37:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T16:37:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T15:51:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/europe/berlin-approves-ukrainian-use-of-german-weapons-to-hit-targets-in-russia", "title": "Berlin Approves Ukrainian Use of German Weapons to Hit Targets in Russia", "body": "The change in stance is meant to address the numerous attacks on Kharkiv that Russia continues to launch from within its own territory. | Image:AP\n\nKyiv: Germany joined the United States on Friday in authorising Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying -- a significant policy change that comes as depleted Ukrainian troops are losing ground in the war. Ukrainian officials have expressed frustration over restrictions on the use of Western weapons -- especially as the border region of Kharkiv has endured a Russian onslaught this month that has stretched Kyiv's outgunned and outmanned forces.\n\nBoth Germany and the US specifically authorised defence of Kharkiv, whose capital city of the same name lies only 20 kilometres (12 miles) from Russia. Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment building in the city overnight, killing at least four people.\n\nBeyond offering Ukraine a chance of better protecting Kharkiv, it's not clear what effect the easing of restrictions might have on the direction of the conflict in what is proving to be a critical period.\n\nThe German government said Ukraine can use weapons it supplies against positions just over the border, from where Russia launches its attacks on Kharkiv. A day earlier, US President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the region, according to US officials familiar with the matter.\n\nThe German announcement brought a furious response from Moscow, where Dmitry Medvedev, the deputy head of Russia's Security Council, said that \"Ukraine and its NATO allies will receive such a devastating response that the alliance won't be able to avoid entering the conflict\" -- an eventuality that Western governments have ruled out.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to ease the restrictions on their weapons because of the risk it would provoke Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometre (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders have pushed for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners.\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in US military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has also slowed crucial deliveries to Ukraine.\n\nThe German government statement noted that, in recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks on the Kharkiv region, in particular from areas just over the border in Russia.\n\n\"Together we are convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement said. \"For this, it can also use the weapons delivered for that purpose in accordance with its international legal commitments, including the ones delivered by us,\" it added, without elaborating on what Berlin called confidential agreements with Kyiv.\n\nBiden's decision allows for US-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official told The Associated Press.\n\nBut the officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the US policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nNATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said Friday he supported lifting the limits on Ukraine's use of Western weaponry, saying it's \"a matter of upholding international law -- Ukraine's right to self-defence.\"\n\nSwedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billstrom noted that his country had not restricted Ukraine's use of its weapons at all, while Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said Rome won't let Kyiv use Italian weapons outside its territory.\n\nIn Moscow, Medvedev repeated Russian warnings that the steps being taken could set NATO and Russia on the path to a nuclear conflict. \"It's not an attempt to scare or any sort of a nuclear bluff,\" he said.\n\nRussia's newly appointed defence minister, Andrei Belousov, claimed Friday that Russian troops are \"advancing in all tactical directions,\" including in the Kharkiv region where he said they have pushed Ukrainian forces back by as much as nine kilometres (5 miles). Russian forces captured 28 towns and villages over the past month, he said.\n\nOverall since the start of the year, Russian forces have taken control of 880 square kilometres (340 square miles) of territory, he added.\n\nIt was not possible to verify his battlefield claims.\n\nOvernight into Friday, Russia launched five ballistic missiles at Kharkiv, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov. At least 25 people were injured, he said.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles -- the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. Russia used the method in Syria's civil war.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy region further north, according to Ukrainian officials.", "source": {"uri": "republicworld.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Republic World"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8155360298", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "15:13:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T15:13:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T15:12:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://abc7news.com/post/president-joe-biden-ukraine-weapons-berlin-lets-ukraine/14895549/", "title": "Ukraine war: US eases stance on Ukraine using weapons on Russian targets; Germany follows suit", "body": "WASHINGTON -- Germany joined the United States on Friday in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying - a significant policy change that comes as depleted Ukrainian troops are losing ground in the war.\n\nUkrainian officials have expressed frustration over restrictions on the use of Western weapons - especially as the border region of Kharkiv has endured a Russian onslaught this month that has stretched Kyiv's outgunned and outmanned forces.\n\nBoth Germany and the U.S. specifically authorized the use of weapons to defend Kharkiv, whose capital city of the same name lies only 20 kilometers (12 miles) from Russia. Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment building in the city overnight, Ukrainian officials said, killing at least five people.\n\nBeyond offering Ukraine a chance of better protecting Kharkiv by targeting Russian capabilities in the region, it's not clear what effect the easing of restrictions might have on the direction of the conflict in what is proving to be a critical period. But it drew a furious response from Moscow and warnings it could draw Russia into war with NATO.\n\nThe German government said Ukraine can use weapons it supplies against positions just over the border, from where Russia launches its attacks on Kharkiv. A day earlier, U.S. President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the region, according to U.S. officials familiar with the matter.\n\nIn response, Dmitry Medvedev, the deputy head of Russia's Security Council, said Friday that \"Ukraine and its NATO allies will receive such a devastating response that the alliance won't be able to avoid entering the conflict\" - an eventuality that Western governments have ruled out.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to ease the restrictions on their weapons because of the risk it would provoke Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict. Last week, Russia said military drills involving tactical nuclear weapons had begun.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders have pushed for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners.\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in U.S. military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has also slowed crucial deliveries to Ukraine.\n\nThe German government statement noted that, in recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks on the Kharkiv region, in particular from areas just over the border in Russia.\n\n\"Together we are convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement said. \"For this, it can also use the weapons delivered for that purpose in accordance with its international legal commitments, including the ones delivered by us,\" it added.\n\nBiden's decision allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official told The Associated Press.\n\nSEE ALSO: At least 16 killed in Russian strike on hardware store in Kharkiv\n\nBut the officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nNATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said Friday he supported lifting the limits on Ukraine's use of Western weaponry, saying it's \"a matter of upholding international law - Ukraine's right to self-defense.\"\n\nSwedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billstr\u00f6m noted that his country had not restricted Ukraine's use of its weapons at all, while Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said Rome won't let Kyiv use Italian weapons outside its territory.\n\nIn Moscow, Medvedev repeated Russian warnings that the steps being taken could set NATO and Russia on the path to a nuclear conflict. \"It's not an attempt to scare or any sort of a nuclear bluff,\" he said.\n\nRussia's newly appointed defense minister, Andrei Belousov, claimed Friday that Russian troops are \"advancing in all tactical directions,\" including in the Kharkiv region where he said they have pushed Ukrainian forces back by as much as 9 kilometers (5 miles). Russian forces captured 28 towns and villages over the past month, he said.\n\nOverall since the start of the year, Russian forces have taken control of 880 square kilometers (340 square miles) of territory, he added.\n\nIt was not possible to verify his battlefield claims.\n\nOvernight into Friday, Russia launched five ballistic missiles at Kharkiv, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov.\n\nFive people were killed, according to Kharkiv Mayor Ihor Terekhov, while the governor said at least 25 were wounded.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles - the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. Russia used the method in Syria's civil war.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy Now, he said, the U.S. is responding to what it has seen in and around the Kharkiv region.\n\n\"Over the past few weeks, Ukraine came to us and asked for the authorization to use weapons that we're providing to defend against this aggression, including against Russian forces that are massing on the Russian side of the border and then attacking into Ukraine,\" Blinken said. \"And that went right to the President and, as you've heard, he's approved use of our weapons for that purpose.\n\n\"Going forward, we'll continue to do what we've been doing, which is as necessary adapt and adjust.\"\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, is 19 miles from the border with Russia.\n\nIt's the second time this year that Biden has quietly relaxed his policy on weapons supplies for Ukraine. Earlier this year, he bent to calls to send long-range missiles known as ATACMS to Kyiv.\n\nThe U.S. is the biggest supplier of weapons to Ukraine in its battle against the full-scale invasion launched by Russian President Vladimir Putin in February 2022.\n\nU.S officials said Thursday that U.S. policy would continue to prohibit the Ukrainian military from using ATACMS, which have a range {"uri": "8155164642", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "13:04:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T13:04:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T13:03:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/berlin-lets-ukraine-use-german-weapons-against-targets-in-russia-after-the-us-also-eases-its-stance/articleshow/110598262.cms", "title": "Berlin lets Ukraine use German weapons against targets in Russia after the US also eases its stance", "body": "Germany and the United States have authorized Ukraine to target some Russian positions on Russian soil with long-range weapons supplied by the West, marking a significant policy shift amid the ongoing conflict. This decision, aimed at defending the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, comes as Ukrainian forces face challenges from Russian attacks in the region. The move has drawn strong reactions from Moscow, with warnings of potential NATO involvement in the conflict. Western leaders have been cautious about easing restrictions on weapons due to fears of provoking Russian President Vladimir Putin.Germany joined the United States on Friday in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying - a significant policy change that comes as depleted Ukrainian troops are losing ground in the war.\n\nUkrainian officials have expressed frustration over restrictions on the use of Western weapons - especially as the border region of Kharkiv has endured a Russian onslaught this month that has stretched Kyiv's outgunned and outmanned forces.\n\nBoth Germany and the U.S. specifically authorized the use of weapons to defend Kharkiv, whose capital city of the same name lies only 20 kilometers (12 miles) from Russia. Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment building in the city overnight, Ukrainian officials said, killing at least five people.\n\nBeyond offering Ukraine a chance of better protecting Kharkiv by targeting Russian capabilities in the region, it's not clear what effect the easing of restrictions might have on the direction of the conflict in what is proving to be a critical period. But it drew a furious response from Moscow and warnings it could draw Russia into war with NATO.\n\nThe German government said Ukraine can use weapons it supplies against positions just over the border, from where Russia launches its attacks on Kharkiv. A day earlier, U.S. President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the region, according to U.S. officials familiar with the matter.\n\nIn response, Dmitry Medvedev, the deputy head of Russia's Security Council, said Friday that \"Ukraine and its NATO allies will receive such a devastating response that the alliance won't be able to avoid entering the conflict\" - an eventuality that Western governments have ruled out.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to ease the restrictions on their weapons because of the risk it would provoke Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict. Last week, Russia said military drills involving tactical nuclear weapons had begun.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders have pushed for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners.\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in U.S. military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has also slowed crucial deliveries to Ukraine.\n\nThe German government statement noted that, in recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks on the Kharkiv region, in particular from areas just over the border in Russia.\n\n\"Together we are convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement said. \"For this, it can also use the weapons delivered for that purpose in accordance with its international legal commitments, including the ones delivered by us,\" it added.\n\nBiden's decision allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official told The Associated Press.\n\nBut the officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nNATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said Friday he supported lifting the limits on Ukraine's use of Western weaponry, saying it's \"a matter of upholding international law - Ukraine's right to self-defense.\"\n\nSwedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billstrom noted that his country had not restricted Ukraine's use of its weapons at all, while Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said Rome won't let Kyiv use Italian weapons outside its territory.\n\nIn Moscow, Medvedev repeated Russian warnings that the steps being taken could set NATO and Russia on the path to a nuclear conflict. \"It's not an attempt to scare or any sort of a nuclear bluff,\" he said.\n\nRussia's newly appointed defense minister, Andrei Belousov, claimed Friday that Russian troops are \"advancing in all tactical directions,\" including in the Kharkiv region where he said they have pushed Ukrainian forces back by as much as 9 kilometers (5 miles). Russian forces captured 28 towns and villages over the past month, he said.\n\nOverall since the start of the year, Russian forces have taken control of 880 square kilometers (340 square miles) of territory, he added.\n\nIt was not possible to verify his battlefield claims.\n\nOvernight into Friday, Russia launched five ballistic missiles at Kharkiv, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov.\n\nFive people were killed, according to Kharkiv Mayor Ihor Terekhov, while the governor said at least 25 were wounded.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles - the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. Russia used the method in Syria's civil war.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy region further north, according to Ukrainian officials.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-374709139", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "16:07:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T16:07:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T15:06:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/news/world/nuclear-threat-no-bluff-us-arms-russia-strike-3085653", "title": "Moscow says nuclear threat no bluff as US confirms arms can strike inside Russia", "body": "Russia says Moscow's conflict with the West is developing according to the worst-case scenario\n\nRussian security chief Dmitry Medvedev said on Friday that Russia was not bluffing about using tactical nuclear weapons after the US and Germany confirmed Ukraine can use their weapons to strike inside Russian territory.\n\nIn a post on Telegram, Mr Medvedev said Moscow's conflict with the West was developing according to the worst-case scenario and that \"no one can rule out it escalating to the last stage.\"\n\nHis comments came after US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said President Joe Biden had approved Ukraine using US-supplied weapons to strike targets inside Russia on targets that were attacking the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv.\n\nMr Blinken said Washington's move marked a change in policy after Mr Biden had previously refused to allow Kyiv to use American weaponry for strikes inside Russia, but he did not specifically say whether the authorisation could expand to include cities and targets deeper inside the country.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference in Prague after an informal meeting of Nato foreign ministers, Mr Blinken said: \"Over the past few weeks, Ukraine came to us and asked for the authorisation to use weapons that we're providing to defend against this aggression, including against Russian forces that are massing on the Russian side of the border and then attacking into Ukraine.\n\n\"And that went right to the President, and as you've heard, he's approved use of our weapons for that purpose. Going forward, we'll continue to do what we've been doing, which is as necessary adapt and adjust.\"\n\nThe change in language comes after Kyiv officials had applied pressure on the US to allows strikes inside Russia to counter Moscw's advances in the towns just north of Kharkiv.\n\nSpeaking to reporters in Stockholm, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Ukraine \"got message from the American side early in the morning\" on Friday which signified a \"step forward\" in defending people in villages near the border with Russia.\n\nHe added: \"I think that using any weapon, Western kind of weapon, on the territory of Russia is a question of time. Otherwise, it is not about just peace.\"\n\nMr Zelensky did not disclose additional details on the communication with the US and questions hang over what restrictions remain in place in relation to the use of long-awaited F-16 fighter jets. But US officials on Thursday confirmed that US policy would continue to prohibit the Ukrainian military from using ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles, and other long-range US-supplied weapons for deep strikes inside Russia.\n\nNato foreign ministers met in the Czech capital on Friday to re-affirm their support for Ukraine, as countries begin to remove restrictions on western-supplied weaponry to counteract Russian advances inside Ukrainian territory.\n\nGermany signalled its openness to Ukraine's use of its weapons to strike military sites fuelling attacks on the Kharkiv region.\n\nA German government spokesperson said: \"We are jointly convinced that Ukraine has the right, guaranteed under international law, to defend itself against these attacks.\n\n\"To do so, it can also use the weapons supplied for this purpose in accordance with its international legal obligations; including those supplied by us.\"\n\nFrance has also re-positioned its stance, giving Ukraine the green light to strike targets inside Russia in response to attacks on Kharkiv.\n\nEarlier this week, France's President, Emmanuel Macron, raised the possibility of sending troops to Ukraine. French authorities are trying to put together a coalition of willing countries to train Ukrainian forces besieged by the Russian army.\n\nAccording to Le Monde, the mission would initially involve \"a few dozen specialists to identify training needs\".\n\n\"Then, in a second phase, a mission of several hundred soldiers. The idea is to train deminers, or even... to train the soldiers of a new motorised brigade.\"\n\nConsultations are likely to accelerate in the next few days, as Mr Zelensky embarks on a visit France to mark the 80th anniversary of the Normandy landings on 6 and 7 June.\n\nThe news comes as Russia continues to attack Kharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, 19 miles (30 km) from the border with Russia. Overnight, ballistic missiles struck an apartment block in Kharkiv, killing at least four people, Ukrainian officials said.\n\nIt came after a missile attack on a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later, according to regional governor Oleh Syniehubov.", "source": {"uri": "inews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "inews.co.uk"}, {"uri": "8155250932", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "13:59:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T13:59:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T13:59:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://euromaidanpress.com/2024/05/31/most-allies-now-support-ukraine-striking-targets-in-russia-italy-and-belgium-oppose-us-undecided/", "title": "Most allies now support Ukraine striking targets in Russia; Italy and Belgium oppose, US undecided", "body": "A key debate has emerged among Ukraine's allies over whether to lift restrictions on Ukraine using Western-supplied weapons to strike targets inside Russia itself. While many allies have provided Ukraine with longer-range weaponry, it has frequently come with the condition that it only be used on Ukrainian soil.\n\nHowever, recent Russian actions like the indiscriminate and massive shelling of Kharkiv and a renewed offensive in the north of that region are prompting some partners to reconsider those limitations.\n\n\"The time has come for allies to consider whether they should lift some of the restrictions they have put on the use of weapons they have donated to Ukraine,\" Stoltenberg said in the interview with the Economist.\n\n\"Especially now when a lot of the fighting is going on in Kharkiv, close to the border, to deny Ukraine the possibility of using these weapons against legitimate military targets on Russian territory makes it very hard for them to defend themselves,\" he added.\n\nThe issue is already being discussed within the European Union and NATO, and based on public statements, a majority of allies now favor removing the restrictions. An increasing number of voices are calling for allowing Ukraine to hit Russian targets with Western arms.\n\nThe UK, Poland, Lithuania, Canada, Latvia, the Netherlands, Sweden, Czechia, France, and Finland believe Ukraine has a legitimate right to strike Russian territory in self-defense.\n\nGermany has also recently inched towards allowing such strikes.\n\nMeanwhile, Belgium and Italy remain opposed to Ukraine using Western arms to strike inside Russia itself.\n\nIn the United States, there is no consensus on whether Ukraine should use American weapons to strike Russia.\n\nThe United States is Ukraine's most influential ally, but until lately, there has been no unified position within the Biden administration on whether Ukraine should be permitted to strike Russia with American weapons.\n\nIn what appears to be a shift of this position, President Joe Biden has reportedly given private permission for Ukraine to use American weapons on Russian soil \"for counter-fire purposes\", meaning \"to hit back at Russian forces hitting them or preparing to hit them.\" However, the permission applies only near Kharkiv, a Ukraine's second-largest city that has been ceaselessly pummeled by Russian cross-border strikes, Politico reported on 30 May.\n\nHowever, the general policy for long-range strikes is still unchanged, unnamed officials familiar with the policy told Politico.\n\nThe issue has been long on the table. A report by Politico from 14 May suggests Ukraine has been pressing the White House to lift the restrictions, prompting active internal debate.\n\n\"The main problem right now is the White House policy to limit our capability\" to strike military targets inside Russia, David Arakhamia, chair of the ruling Servant of the People party in the Ukrainian parliament, said during a visit to Washington this week.\n\nUkraine strikes Russian territory with Western arms, most recently against Krasnodar - AFP\n\nSecretary of State Antony Blinken initiated the discussion after what he called a \"sobering trip to Kyiv,\" arguing that Ukraine needs to be allowed to hit Russian targets. In Kyiv, he said the US is not encouraging such strikes but that the decision is ultimately up to Ukraine.\n\nSimilarly, House Speaker Mike Johnson stated Ukraine needs to be able to wage war as it sees fit. Besides, a bipartisan group of US lawmakers has also urged the Pentagon to allow the strikes, saying the current Biden policy handcuffs Ukraine's ability to resist Russian forces.\n\nAmong European countries, Belgium and Italy still do not support strikes on Russian territory using Western weapons.\n\nUntil lately, Germany was also among the hesitant, but this is now changing.\n\nOn 26 May, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz still maintained he sees no reason to expand the zone where Ukraine can employ German military aid, saying the established rules agreed with Kyiv are working well.\n\n\"There are clear rules that have been agreed with Ukraine and that apply to the supply of German weapons. At least, that is my position,\" he said, adding that his policy toward Ukraine aims to \"prevent the conflict from escalating into a major war.\"\n\nHowever, on 28 May, Scholz was reported by Politico as saying that German weapons could be used \"within the framework of international law.\" The next day, his spokesperson Steffen Hebestreit clarified to reporters that Ukraine's \"defensive action is not limited to one's own territory, but [can] also be expanded to the territory of the aggressor,\" according to Politico.\n\nA person familiar with the position of the German government claimed, speaking with Politico on condition of anonymity, that Scholz supports allowing the use of Western weapons against targets on Russian territory. However, this source did not provide any further details.\n\nMeanwhile, Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni dismissed Stoltenberg's position as \"counterproductive.\" \"I don't know why Stoltenberg said that, I think we have to be very careful,\" Meloni stated.\n\nBelgian Prime Minister reiterated that Belgium and Ukraine previously agreed that the use of Belgian military assistance outside Ukrainian territory is out of the question. He said this during a joint press conference with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in Brussels.\n\n\"Everything that is stipulated in the agreement, military equipment, military materials, must be used by the Armed Forces on Ukrainian territory, we have signed such an agreement,\" said Alexander De Croo.\n\nFinland informed as early as February that it had placed no restrictions on how its weapons could be used, implicitly green-lighting cross-border strikes. Britain's foreign secretary recently confirmed Ukraine's right to do so, stating that Russia is attacking Ukrainian territory, and it's completely understandable that Ukraine feels the need to defend itself.\n\nPoland supports Ukraine striking targets in Russia since, as Foreign Minister Radoslaw Sikorski said, Russia is not constraining itself, attacking Ukrainian power grids, grain terminals, gas storage and civilian infrastructure while stopping short of using nuclear weapons.\n\nLithuania's foreign minister admitted allies erred originally by limiting Ukraine but now need to grant more freedom to strike Russian targets.\n\n\"We made a mistake from the very beginning by restricting the Ukrainians, because it could have been seen as an escalation,\" Gabrielius Landsbergis said.\n\nAccording to him, Ukraine should be able to use the equipment provided to achieve its strategic objectives, including \"strikes on Russian territory, supply lines and troops preparing to attack Ukraine. Only one side is subject to the rules. We must abandon these rules that we have created ourselves.\"\n\nLatvian President Edgars Rinkevics believes the current Russian offensive results from allies' indecisiveness, saying,\n\n\"What we see is the consequence of our inability to provide Ukraine with weapons and also putting restrictions [on using] those weapons to strike military targets in Russia.\"\n\nHe saw no rational reason to preserve the ban for Ukraine and dismissed fears Russia could use tactical nuclear weapons as unfounded.\n\nThe American Institute for the Study of War believes that Western restrictions on using Western weapons to strike targets in Russia have allowed the Russian military to create a safe foothold from which Russian aircraft can launch guided bombs and missiles at Ukrainian positions. Ground troops and equipment can also move freely along the border before engaging in combat.\n\nStriking Russian territory with Western-supplied weapons would allow Ukraine to hit staging areas, logistics hubs, ammo depots, and other strategic military assets inside Russia that are being used to support and enable the Russian offensives into Ukrainian territory. It would also help counter Russia's ability to strike Ukrainian cities and infrastructure from its own territory using aircraft, missiles, and long-range artillery while staying out of range of Ukraine's current weaponry.\n\nAs it stands, the restrictions give Russia an advantage in being able to maneuver and concentrate forces close to the border before attacks. Ukraine would be able to degrade Russia's air defenses inside Russian territory, making it easier for Ukrainian strikes against Russian forces in occupied Ukrainian areas.\n\nCalls for Ukraine to stop defending itself are immoral, Nobel laureate Matviichuk says\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy previously cited two reasons the West hesitates to allow counterstrikes on Russian soil.\n\nAccording to him, the West's primary reason for hesitating - fear of nuclear escalation - was overblown because Putin would refrain from using nuclear weapons out of a sense of self-preservation. In an interview with the New York Times, Zelenskyy also suggested that there was another reason for the West's hesitation: Some countries were seeking to retain trade and diplomatic ties with Russia. \"Everyone keeps the door slightly ajar,\" he said.\n\nAnother divisive issue allies are grappling with is the potential deployment of troops to Ukraine, with nations similarly split on the prospect.", "source": {"uri": "euromaidanpress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Euromaidan Press"}, "authors": [{"uri": "orysia_hrudka@euromaidanpress.com", "name": "Orysia Hrudka", "type": {"uri": "2024-05-374739968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "16:39:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T16:39:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T16:37:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/05/31/europe/us-weapons-ukraine-strike-russia-kharkiv-intl/index.html", "title": "Is the US decision on Ukraine weapons a game-changer?", "body": "The story of the past 27 months since Russia invaded Ukraine has been one of crumbling taboos. After repelling Russia's initial march on Kyiv, Ukraine has asked its Western allies for greater and greater support: first ammunition, then tanks, then cluster munitions, then fighter jets.\n\nEach time, the West has agonized over whether to grant Kyiv's latest request, fearing escalation and a potential Russian response. Each time, the taboo was broken - and nothing happened. What seemed beyond the pale one week had become banal the next.\n\nBut the rhythm of deliberation and delay has been hard to shake. Despite securing more weapons from the United States last month, Ukraine has not been able to use them as it pleases. As Moscow this month launched its surprise assault on the northeastern Kharkiv region, Washington forbade Kyiv from using US weapons to strike targets inside Russia.\n\nThis too crumbled. President Joe Biden this week gave Ukraine permission to carry out limited strikes using US weapons in Russian territory around Kharkiv, after several European nations had removed restrictions on how the weapons they have given to Kyiv can be used.\n\n\"Over the past few weeks, Ukraine came to us and asked for the authorization to use weapons that were provided to defend against this aggression\" near Kharkiv city, \"including against Russian forces that are massing on the Russian side of the border,\" US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Friday on a visit to Prague, the Czech capital. He confirmed Biden had approved Ukraine's request.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky praised the decision as a \"step forward\" which will help his forces to defend the embattled Kharkiv region.\n\nWhile the decision may mark a new phase of the war, analysts have questioned whether the new freedoms will significantly bolster Ukraine's ability to repel Russia's invasion.\n\nSome are bullish. This month, the calls for the US to remove the restrictions became more desperate, as Russia continue to pummel Kharkiv city with missiles and make gains elsewhere in the region.\n\nFirefighters work at a hardware store targeted by a Russian air strike in Kharkiv, May 25, 2024.\n\nValentyn Ogirenko/Reuters\n\nIn a CNN op-ed, Adam Kinzinger and Ben Hodges described the bizarre effect of the US taboo: \"We have heard Ukrainian soldiers repeatedly tell stories of Russian columns attacking, being repelled, and retreating to safe Russian territory to regroup, have a hot meal, plan and attack again.\"\n\n\"Ukraine cannot win if Russians can attack civilian targets with impunity and call 'time out' in their own territory,\" they wrote, urging Biden to call his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin's bluff.\n\nBut military analysts have tempered expectations, partly because the US is standing firm in not allowing Ukraine to use the most formidable munition it has been given to fire into Russia: the long-range missiles known as ATACMS that can hit targets 300 kilometers (nearly 200 miles) away.\n\nInstead, Ukraine can only use shorter-range missiles known as GMLRS, which have a range of around 70 kilometers (around 40 miles).\n\nKateryna Stepanenko, an analyst at the Institute for the Study of War in Washington, told CNN the policy change will \"blunt\" Russia's offensive in Kharkiv, but still \"preserves the majority of Russia's sanctuary space.\"\n\n\"The policy still protects Russia's operational and deep rear sufficiently that this change near Kharkiv Oblast is insufficient to bring about a turning point in the war. Ukraine particularly needs the capacity to strike deep rear areas to defeat the Russian ground and air threats, as many Russian airfields that support strikes against Ukrainian cities are located outside of the allowed GMLRS range,\" she said.\n\nElderly Ukrainians wait to be evacuated from the city of Vovchansk as Russia advances in Kharkiv region, May 20, 2024.\n\nNarciso Contreras/Anadolu/Getty Images\n\nFranz-Stefan Gady, an associate fellow at the International Institute for Strategic Studies, told CNN the GMLRS cross-border strikes will allow Ukraine \"to hit some Russian staging areas, command and control centers, as well as supply depots. It will not stop but complicate Russian military operations against Kharkhiv.\"\n\n\"We need to be realistic about what can be expected from this policy change, since the Russian armed forces have already adapted to the introduction of ground-based precision fires,\" he said.\n\nMathieu Boulegue, a researcher at the Center for European Policy Analysis, said the policy change would allow Ukraine to \"be more efficient when it comes to repelling attacks and pushing back preemptively.\"\n\n\"It's not a game changer, per se. It's an add-on, a steroid, an extra booster for Ukraine to defend itself,\" he said.\n\nRed lines fade\n\nThe US is joining the United Kingdom, France, Germany and several others in removing restrictions on how Ukraine uses the weapons it is given.\n\nBefore Biden gave the green light, Putin had made veiled nuclear threats to countries considering allowing Ukraine to strike Russia with their weapons. He warned the move could lead to \"serious consequences,\" particularly for \"small and densely populated countries.\"\n\nAs well as making nuclear threats, Putin also signaled earlier this month that he was open to peace talks.\n\n\"All of these false narratives deliberately aimed to discourage Western decisionmakers from allowing Ukraine to preempt Russia's attack on Kharkiv city,\" Stepanenko said.\n\nWhile the removal of this taboo appears to mark a new chapter in the war, Russia has previously experienced Ukrainian strikes with Western weapons on territory it considers its own.\n\nUkraine has frequently targeted occupied Crimea, which Russia annexed in 2014, using \"Storm Shadow\" missiles provided by the UK.\n\nUkraine also launched strikes on Kharkiv and Kherson in late 2022, as it sought to liberate the regions occupied by Russia in the early weeks of the full-scale invasion.\n\nIn both cases, Russia had warned Ukraine and its Western allies not to cross its red line. In both cases, Ukraine and its Western allies ignored the warning.\n\n\"The Kremlin already regards strikes against occupied Crimea and Donetsk, Luhansk, Kherson, and Zaporizhia oblasts as 'strikes against Russia,' but the reality is that there are few things that Russia can do to further escalate its war in Ukraine without incurring major risks,\" Stepanenko said.\n\nCNN's Alex Marquardt, Jennifer Hansler, Kylie Atwood, Niamh Kennedy and Anna Chernova contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, "authors": [{"uri": This move follows Kyiv's request for authorization from Washington. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken confirmed the move, stating that it was a result of the US strategy of adjusting and adapting to the battleground. Biden has relaxed his policy on weapons supplies for Ukraine twice this year, earlier this year, he resisted calls to send long-range missiles to Kyiv. U.S. President Joe Biden approved Ukraine using U.S. weapons to strike targets inside Russia that were attacking the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, after Kyiv sought authorization from Washington in recent weeks, U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken confirmed on Friday.\n\nSpeaking at a news conference in Prague after an informal meeting of NATO foreign ministers, Blinken did not specifically say whether Biden's authorization could expand to include other Russian cities and targets that are deeper inside Russia.\n\nHe said Washington's move, a marked change in policy by Biden, who had steadfastly refused to allow Ukraine to use American weaponry for strikes inside Russia, was a result of U.S. strategy of adjusting and adapting to the battleground. Now, he said, the U.S. is responding to what it has seen in and around the Kharkiv region.\n\n\"Over the past few weeks, Ukraine came to us and asked for the authorization to use weapons that we're providing to defend against this aggression, including against Russian forces that are massing on the Russian side of the border and then attacking into Ukraine,\" Blinken said.\n\n\"And that went right to the President, and as you've heard, he's approved use of our weapons for that purpose. Going forward, we'll continue to do what we've been doing, which is as necessary adapt and adjust,\" Blinken said.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, is 19 miles (30 km) from the border with Russia.\n\nIt is the second time this year that Biden has quietly relaxed his policy on weapons supplies for Ukraine. Earlier this year, he bent to calls to send long-range missiles known as ATACMS to Kyiv.\n\nThe U.S. is the biggest supplier of weapons to Ukraine in its battle against the full-scale invasion launched by Russian President Vladimir Putin in February 2022.\n\nU.S officials said on Thursday that U.S. policy would continue to prohibit the Ukrainian military from using ATACMS, which have a
